awd_titl_txt: CNS: Small: Towards Intelligent, Coordinated and Scalable Management of Server Sprinting in Edge Data Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
Built at numerous distributed locations in proximity to end users, edge data centers are essential ingredients of the next-generation computing paradigm to enable ultra-low latency- for emerging services such as augmented reality and assisted driving. Because of high capital expenses and/or limited physical space, however, the infrastructure capacity of edge data centers is often severely constrained and difficult to scale up for accommodating the constantly growing demand. To overcome the capacity constraint without compromising data center availability, this project exploits two important resources --- distributed energy storage devices (such as battery units) and cold air thermal energy storage --- and transforms them into server sprinting  enablers for delivering the best service quality. The key contribution of this project is an intelligent and scalable framework based on state-of-the-art reinforcement learning, which holistically coordinates servers' sprinting decisions on the fly for maximizing the system-wide performance in highly dynamic and practical environments. This project considers two complementary types of edge data centers: those where the physical infrastructure and servers are managed by a single entity; and those where different tenants house their own servers and the physical infrastructure is controlled by the data center operator.

This project can push the performance beyond the currently achievable limit in edge data centers, translating into better service quality and higher user satisfaction without costly infrastructure capacity expansion. It extends the exploration of computer system optimization to a new paradigm where scalable online learning is the core, and thus can catalyze a shift in future system designs.  This project also contains a significant educational component and provides broad opportunities to attract a diverse population of students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Edge data centers are integral to the next-generation computing paradigm, enabling ultra-low latency services for applications such as real-time AI inference and assisted driving. However, these data centers often face severe infrastructure and resource constraints due to high costs and limited physical space, making it challenging to scale up to meet the rapidly growing demand. This challenge is exacerbated in environments with unreliable power supplies. Addressing these constraints requires an intelligent and scalable framework that holistically coordinates resource management decisions in real-time to maximize system-wide performance in dynamic and practical settings.

This project supported our research to develop novel resource management algorithms that advance resource efficiency and system resilience in edge data centers. Specifically, the focus was on resource-constrained edge data centers, where novel algorithms were designed using interdisciplinary tools such as reinforcement learning, online optimization, and control theory. These algorithms enable coordinated server management, improving resource efficiency and maximizing system-wide performance under time-varying resource constraints. Additionally, they can be integrated seamlessly with state-of-the-art resource management techniques to optimize individual applications' power-cost-resilience tradeoffs at runtime. 

The algorithms developed in this project represent emerging efforts to leverage interdisciplinary methodologies for efficient and coordinated resource management in edge data centers. Furthermore, the techniques and methodologies from this research, such as sample-efficient deep reinforcement learning for edge systems, can extend to other domains, potentially advancing innovations beyond edge data centers.

This project also addressed the limitations of conventional approaches to leveraging machine learning in resource management, which often lack robustness guarantees. To tackle this, this project developed learning augmented algorithms that incorporate trusted expert algorithms to safeguard machine learning predictions. These algorithms utilize novel reservation costs to hedge against future risks while closely following machine learning predictions. This approach provides theoretical robustness guarantees, even when predictions are of low quality due to abrupt system load changes, distribution shifts, or even malicious model modifications. This project demonstrated the efficacy of these learning-augmented algorithms across various scenarios, including edge data centers powered by replenishable renewable energy sources.

While the primary application of this research is in edge data centers, the developed algorithms have broader implications. For instance, in an AI-powered electric vehicle (EV) charging station system, where EV-level information (e.g., charging demand and departure time) is often estimated with potentially large prediction errors, the learning-augmented algorithms provide a robust framework for managing such inaccuracies. These tools offer new perspectives for optimizing complex real-world systems under uncertainty.

As part of this grant, the PI supported multiple PhD students including female students, who have published their work in top-tier venues. The research findings were also integrated into the curriculum at UCR, exposing students to cutting-edge advancements in resource management and sustainability for edge data centers.
